facts.text: Civil Appeal Nos. 202 and 203 of 1965 filed in Supreme Court.

facts.text: Appeals from judgment and decree dated December 21, 1961 of Madras High Court in O.S. Appeals Nos. 55 and 56 of 1959.

anchor.surface_text: Appeals from the judgment and decree dated December 21, 1961 of the Madras High Court in O. S. Appeals Nos. 55 and 56 of 1959.

facts.text: Appellant is a limited company carrying on transport business in South Arcot District.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant is a limited Company carrying on transport business in South Arcot District.

facts.text: M.A. Khader holds 13 shares in the company and is respondent in Civil Appeal No. 202 of 1965.

anchor.surface_text: M. A. Khader, the contesting respondent in Civil Appeal No. 202 of 1965, holds 13 shares and his brother,

facts.text: M.A. Jabbar holds 163 shares in the company and is respondent in Civil Appeal No. 203 of 1965.

anchor.surface_text: M. A. Jabbar, the contesting respondent in Civil Appeal No. 203 of 1965, holds 163 shares in the Company.

facts.text: On January 2, 1957, board of directors passed resolution calling unpaid amount of Rs. 25/- on each share.

anchor.surface_text: On January 2, 1957, the board of directors of the Company passed a resolution calling the unpaid amount of Rs. 25/- on each share.

facts.text: On January 3, 1957, call notice issued to shareholders requesting payment on or before January 19, 1957.

anchor.surface_text: On January 3, 1957, a call notice was issued to the shareholders requesting payment on or before January 19, 1957.

facts.text: Call notices were duly served on the contesting respondents.

anchor.surface_text: The call notices were duly served on the contesting respondents.

facts.text: Call monies remained unpaid.

anchor.surface_text: As the call monies remained unpaid, the Company issued the

facts.text: On January 20, 1957, company issued notice under Art. 29 to respondents requiring payment by January 30, 1957 with interest and expenses.

anchor.surface_text: following notice dated January 20, 1957 to the respondents under Art. 29 Sir, As the call amount of the balance of Rs. 25/- for every share held by you remains unpaid

facts.text: Respondents did not pay the call monies despite notice dated January 20, 1957.

anchor.surface_text: In spite of this notice, the respondents did not pay the call monies,

facts.text: On February 11, 1957, board of directors passed resolution under Art. 30 forfeiting shares held by respondents.

anchor.surface_text: and on February 11, 1957, the board of directors passed a resolution under Art. 30 forfeiting the shares held by them.

facts.text: On November 8, 1957, respondents filed two separate applications under s.155 of Companies Act, 1956 in Madras High Court praying to set aside forfeitures and rectify share register.

anchor.surface_text: On November 8, 1957, the respondents filed two separate applications under s. 155 of the Indian Companies Act, 1956 in the High Court of Madras praying that the forfeitures be set aside

facts.text: Ramachandra Ayyar J. allowed the applications and ordered rectification of registers.

anchor.surface_text: Ramachandra Ayyar, J. allowed the applications, and passed consequential orders for rectification of the registers

facts.text: Decision of Ramachandra Ayyar J. affirmed by appellate court in Madras High Court.

anchor.surface_text: and his decision was affirmed by the appellate Court.

facts.text: Courts below held notice dated January 20, 1957 defective due to absence of particulars of interest and expenses, forfeiture invalid.

anchor.surface_text: The Courts below held that in the absence of Particulars of interest and expenses, the notice dated January 20, 1957 was defective and the forfeiture is invalid.

facts.text: Supreme Court appeals by certificate granted by High Court.

anchor.surface_text: The Company now appeals to this Court by on a certificate granted by the High Court.

facts.text: Supreme Court held notice dated January 20, 1957 defective in respect of demand for expenses as amount not disclosed.

anchor.surface_text: But we agree with the High Court that the notice is defective in respect of the demand for expenses. The amount of expenses incurred by the Company by reason of the non-payment was not disclosed.

facts.text: Supreme Court held forfeiture invalid due to defective notice under Art. 29.

anchor.surface_text: A proper notice under Art. 29 is a condition precedent to forfeiture, under Art. 30. Here, the notice under Art. 29 is defective, and the condition precedent is not complied with.

facts.text: On January 18, 1957, M.A. Jabbar, M.A. Khader and others filed Application No. 119 of 1957 in Madras High Court under ss.402 and 237, obtained interim stay of collection pursuant to Jan 3 notice.

anchor.surface_text: On January 18, 1957, M. A. Jabbar, M. A. Khadir and other shareholders filed Application No. 119 of 1957 in the Madras High Court praying for reliefs under ss. 402 and 237

facts.text: Stay order in Application 119/1957 communicated to directors on January 21, 1957 after Jan 20 notice issued.

anchor.surface_text: The stay order was communicated to the directors on January 21, 1957 after the notice of the intended forfeiture dated January 20, 1957 was issued.

facts.text: On January 30, 1957, court passed modified interim order restraining forfeiture and directing M.A. Jabbar to pay call money into court within one week.

anchor.surface_text: On January 30, 1957, the Court passed a modified interim order restraining the forfeiture of the shares, and directed M. A. Jabbar to pay the call money into Court within one week.

facts.text: Call money not paid into court as directed on January 30, 1957.

anchor.surface_text: The call money was not paid into Court,

facts.text: On February 8, 1957, court vacated the stay order in Application 119/1957.

anchor.surface_text: and on February 8, 1957, the Court vacated the stay order.

facts.text: Application No. 119 of 1957 dismissed on April 10, 1957.

anchor.surface_text: Application No. 119 of 1957 was eventually dismissed on April 10, 1957.

Articles 29 and 30 of the Articles of Association of the Company read The numberice shall name a future day, number being less than seven days from the service of the numberice, on or before which such all or other money and all interest and expenses that may have accrued by reason of such number-payment are to be paid and the place where payment is to be made, the place so named being either registered office of the Company are usually made payable and shall state that in the event of number-payment at or before the time and at the place appointed the share in respect of which such payment is due, will be liable to be forfeited.

concepts.interpretation: Requires notice naming day for payment of call money, interest, expenses, stating forfeiture consequence if unpaid; must disclose amount of expenses to enable payment.

anchor.surface_text: On January 18, 1957, M. A. Jabbar, M. A. Khadir and other shareholders filed Application No. 119 of 1957 in the Madras High Court praying for reliefs under ss. 402 and 237

under Art. 29 Sir, As the call amount of the balance of Rs. 25/- for every share held by you remains unpaid in respect of the numberice dated 3rd January 1957 issued in pursuance of the resolution of the Board, I hereby issue this numberice calling upon you to pay the called amount at the registered office of the Company on or before Wednesday the 30th January 1957, together with interest at six per cent and any expenses that might have accrued by reason of such number-payment. Take further numberice that in the event of number- payment as mentioned above, the shares registered in your name will be liable to be, once for all, forfeited without further numberice and without prejudice to any legal action that may be taken against you for recovering the balance amount due from you treating the same as a debt due to and recoverable as such by the Company under Article 14.

concepts.unlisted_label: Discretionary Jurisdiction under S.155 Companies Act

issues.text: Whether the notice dated January 20, 1957 is defective in respect of the demand for interest

anchor.surface_text: In all standard articles of a company, the regulations relating to calls provide for payment of interest on the unpaid call money at a certain rate from the date appointed for its payment up to the time of actual payment, see regulation 14 of Table A in the first Schedule to the Indian Companies Act, 1913, regulation 16 of Tabie A in the first Schedule to the Indian Companies Act, 1956 and Palmers Company Precedents, 17th Edn., Part 1, p. 437 and the regulations relating to calls are followed by regulations relating to Forfeiture like Arts. 29 and 30 of the appellant Company. In the light of Art. 29 read with similar regulations relating to calls, we would have no difficulty in holding that the notice dated January 20, 1957 required payment of Interest on the call money from the date appointed for the payment thereof, that is to say, January 19, 1957 up to the time of the actual payment. Unfortunately, all the regulations of the Company relating to payment of calls have not been printed in the paper book, and in the present state of the record, we express no opinion on the question whether the notice is defective in respect of the demand for interest.

issues.text: Whether the notice dated January 20, 1957 is defective in respect of the demand for expenses

anchor.surface_text: But we agree with the High Court that the notice is defective in respect of the demand for expenses. The amount of expenses incurred by the Company by reason of the non-payment was not disclosed. The respondents were not informed how much they should pay on account of the expenses. The object of the notice under Art. 29 is to give the shareholder an opportunity for payment of the call money, interest and expenses. The notice under Art. 29 must disclose to the shareholder presumably conversant with the Articles sufficient information from which he may know with certainty the amount which he should pay in order to avoid the forfeiture.

issues.text: Whether a proper notice under Article 29 is a condition precedent to forfeiture under Article 30

anchor.surface_text: In the absence of particulars of the expenses, the respondents were not in a position to know the precise amount which they were required to pay on account of the expenses. A proper notice under Art. 29 is a condition precedent to forfeiture, under Art. 30. Here, the notice under Art. 29 is defective, and the condition precedent is not complied with. The slight defect in the notice invalidates it and is fatal to the forfeiture.

issues.text: Whether the omission of the respondents' names from the share register was without sufficient cause under Section 155(1)(a)(ii) of the Companies Act, 1956, attracting jurisdiction for rectification

anchor.surface_text: The Courts below, therefore, rightly declared that the forfeiture was invalid. Section 155 1 a ii of the Indian Companies Act allows rectification of the share register if the name of any person after having been entered in the register is, without sufficient cause, omitted therefrom. There is no sufficient cause for the omission of the name of the shareholder from the register, where the omission is due to an invalid forfeiture of his shares, and on finding that the forfeiture is invalid, the Court has ample jurisdiction under s. 155 to order rectification of the register.

issues.text: Whether the contention as to the invalidity of the notice dated January 20, 1957 was open to the respondents in the absence of specific pleading

anchor.surface_text: Counsel for the appellant contended that the point as to the invalidity of the notice dated January 20, 1957 was not open to the respondents in the absence of any pleading on this point. In the affidavit in support of the application, the respondents pleaded that the steps prescribed before there can be a forfeiture, have not been complied with. No further particulars were given, but the contention as to the invalidity of the notice dated January 20. 1957 was pointedly raised in the argument in the first Court. The contention was allowed to be raised without objection.

issues.text: Whether the respondents waived or abandoned their right to challenge the forfeiture by reason of the proceedings in Application No. 119 of 1957

anchor.surface_text: Counsel for the appellant contended that 1 by reason of the aforesaid proceedings the respondents waived and abandoned their right to challenge the forfeiture 2 the order dated January 30. 1957 substituted a fresh notice of intended forfeiture under Art, 29 in lieu of the original notice dated January 20, 1957 and in the absence of compliance with this order, the forfeiture is valid. Neither of these contentions was raised in the Court below.

issues.text: Whether the Court should refuse discretionary relief under Section 155

anchor.surface_text: We find nothing in the proceedings in Application No. 119 of 1957 from which we can infer a waiver or abandonment by the respondents of their right to challenge the validity of the notice dated January 20, 1957 and the subsequent forfeiture. We also fail to see how the order of the Court dated January 30, 1957 can amount to a notice under Art. 29. The only notice under Art. 29 is the one dated January 20, 1957, and as that notice is defective, the forfeiture is invalid. Counsel for the appellant contended that the relief under s. 155 is discretionary, and the Court should have refused relief in the exercise of its discretion.

holdings.text: The notice dated January 20, 1957 is defective in respect of the demand for expenses because the amount of expenses was not disclosed.

anchor.surface_text: But we agree with the High Court that the notice is defective in respect of the demand for expenses. The amount of expenses incurred by the Company by reason of the non-payment was not disclosed. The respondents were not informed

holdings.reasoning_summary: Art. 29 requires notice to disclose sufficient information for shareholder to know exact amount to pay to avoid forfeiture; no amount for expenses given.

holdings.text: The object of the notice under Art. 29 is to give the shareholder an opportunity to pay call money, interest and expenses by disclosing sufficient information on the amount required.

anchor.surface_text: The object of the notice under Art. 29 is to give the shareholder an opportunity for payment of the call money, interest and expenses. The notice under Art. 29 must disclose to the shareholder

holdings.reasoning_summary: Shareholder must know precise amount to pay; absence of particulars prevents compliance.

holdings.text: A proper notice under Art. 29 is a condition precedent to forfeiture under Art. 30; defective notice invalidates forfeiture.

anchor.surface_text: A proper notice under Art. 29 is a condition precedent to forfeiture, under Art. 30. Here, the notice under Art. 29 is defective, and the condition precedent is not complied with.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Art. 30 forfeiture requires prior compliance with Art. 29 notice; slight defect fatal.

holdings.text: The forfeiture was invalid due to defective notice under Art. 29.

anchor.surface_text: The slight defect in the notice invalidates it and is fatal to the forfeiture. The Courts below, therefore, rightly declared that the forfeiture was invalid.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Defect in condition precedent notice renders subsequent forfeiture invalid.

holdings.text: Omission of shareholder's name from register due to invalid forfeiture is without sufficient cause under s.155(1)(a)(ii), attracting jurisdiction for rectification.

anchor.surface_text: Section 155 1   a   ii  of the Indian Companies Act allows rectification of the share register if the name of any person after having been entered in the register is, without sufficient cause, omitted therefrom.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Invalid forfeiture provides no sufficient cause for omission; court has jurisdiction under s.155.

holdings.text: The issue under s.155(1)(a)(ii) is whether name omitted without sufficient cause, not whether shareholder has sufficient cause.

anchor.surface_text: The issue under s. 155 1  a  ii  is not whether the shareholder has sufficient cause but whether his name has been omitted from the register without sufficient cause.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory language focuses on cause for omission by company, not shareholder's cause.

holdings.text: Contention of notice invalidity was open to respondents despite absence of specific pleading.

anchor.surface_text: Counsel for the appellant contended that the point as to the invalidity of the notice dated January 20, 1957 was not open to the respondents in the absence of any pleading on this point.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Pleading referred to non-compliance with steps for forfeiture; point raised in argument without objection.

holdings.text: No waiver or abandonment of right to challenge forfeiture inferred from proceedings in Application No. 119 of 1957.

anchor.surface_text: We find nothing in the proceedings in Application No. 119 of 1957 from which we can infer a waiver or abandonment by the respondents of their right to challenge

holdings.reasoning_summary: Proceedings unrelated to validity of notice; no inference of waiver.

holdings.text: Court order dated January 30, 1957 does not amount to a notice under Art. 29.

anchor.surface_text: We also fail to see how the order of the Court dated January 30, 1957 can amount to a notice under Art. 29.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Only notice under Art. 29 was dated Jan 20, which was defective.

holdings.text: Relief under s.155 not to be refused in exercise of discretion where summary decision appropriate and forfeiture invalid.

anchor.surface_text: But the point as to the Invalidity of the notice dated January 20, 1957 could well be decided summarily, and the Courts below rightly decided to give relief

holdings.reasoning_summary: Discretion not arbitrary; where facts simple and right clear, summary jurisdiction proper.

holdings.text: Clean hands maxim inapplicable; respondents assert legal right to shares due to invalid forfeiture, not equitable relief.

anchor.surface_text: The respondents are not seeking equitable relief against forfeiture. They are asserting their legal right to the shares on the ground that the forfeiture is invalid

holdings.reasoning_summary: Legal right enforcement; unrelated conduct not relevant to relief.

holdings.text: Clean hands maxim applies only to conduct related to subject-matter of litigation.

anchor.surface_text: , and they continue to be the legal owners of the shares. Secondly, the maxim does not mean that every improper conduct of the applicant disentitles him to equitable relief.
